 Gross Profit Margin: Efficiency in production.
 Operating Profit Margin: Core business profitability.

 Why it matters: Strong cash flow isn't enough if margins are poor!

 Current Ratio: Pay liabilities with assets.
 Quick Ratio: Excludes inventory for stricter assessment.
 Cash Ratio: Immediate cash for obligations.
 Importance: Low liquidity risks insolvency, despite cash flow.

ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† & ğ—Ÿğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—´ğ—² ğ—¥ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ˜€: ğ—œğ˜€ ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ——ğ—²ğ—¯ğ˜ ğ— ğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²?
 Debt-to-Equity Ratio: Evaluates leverage risk.

ğ—˜ğ—³ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† ğ—¥ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ˜€ â€“ ğ—”ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—¨ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—˜ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¹ğ˜†?
 Asset Turnover Ratio: Efficiency in using assets to generate revenue.

 Return on Assets (ROA): How efficiently assets generate profit.
 Return on Equity (ROE): Profitability relative to shareholder equity.
 Return on Investment (ROI): The effectiveness of investment decisions.
 Why it matters: Investors focus on returns, not just cash flow.

ğ—šğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜ğ—µ & ğ—©ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¥ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ˜€ â€“ ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ—”ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—•ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€?
 ğ—˜arnings Per Share (EPS): Profits allocated to each share of stock.
 Price-to-Earnings (P/E) Ratio: Investor confidence in future earnings.
 Market-to-Book Ratio: Compares market valuation to book value.

ğŸ„â€â™‚ï¸ Scott Leese
ğŸ„â€â™‚ï¸ Scott Leese
postsData.content:
Job security is a f***ing myth.

Proof: Luka (top 3 player in NBA) just got traded for injury-prone Anthony Davis.

Think your 136% quota attainment will save you?
Nah.

It's not because you're doing a bad job.

9/10 times... it's because senior leadership is clueless.

- CFO: "We can save 'X' dollars by cutting our sales team"
- CEO: "We should just keep our best salespeople and cut the rest"
- CRO: "We can be 10X more productive by replacing our SDRs with AI"

And when sh-t hits the fan, they NEVER take accountability.

...I can point out tons of these people.
I've seen it happen time and time again.

If the Mavericks are stupid enough to trade away their future, what makes you think your job will keep you?

They don't care about you.

Better have a backup plan to protect yourself.

comments.commentText:
I get the point of the post but...

"Doncic has been out since suffering a calf strain on Christmas Day against the Timberwolves, but that's just been the beginning of his injuries this season. He with a calf contusion in the preseason, while also battling knee, groin and wrist injuries.
He was also beat up throughout last year's run to the NBA Finals, getting pain injections before every game, leaving games with nearly every body part wrapped in ice or heat packs, and limping severely in every playoff round. His conditioning has been a concern for the last few years, but for the Mavericks to make this kind of move must mean it's pretty severe." - Sports Illustrated

As a lifelong Mavs fan this hurts but is so true in business. It's like a rep getting fired after making presidents club 5 yrs in a row, because they didn't make more dials than everyone else. 

â€ï¸

It's what Nico missed, and what has destroyed the Mavs fanbase. His leadership betrayed the fans.

Sales leaders will kill the culture when they make moves like this.

Teams need clarity of vision to act, and moves like this are just confusing in sports or business.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely spot on! Job security is fragile in this landscape. Always best to have a backup plan and stay adaptable. #CareerResilience

postsData.name:
Ian Koniak
Ian Koniak
postsData.content:
Here are the 5 biggest mistakes AE's make during Discovery:

(And how to fix them)

Are your discovery meetings falling short of your own expectations?

If so, you're not alone.

Many salespeople struggle with running effective discovery meetings, but the good news is that there are concrete steps you can take to turn things around.

Here are my Top 5 reasons why discovery meetings often fail, along with tips for how to avoid these common pitfalls:

1. Lack of preparation:

If you don't do your research on the prospect and their business before the meeting, you won't be able to ask relevant questions or provide valuable insights. This can make the prospect feel like you don't understand their needs and can damage the relationship.

2. Poor communication:

If you don't set clear goals for the meeting or communicate them effectively to the prospect upfront, you may end up talking past each other or not covering important topics. Frame the meeting before starting so they know the focus is on discovery, rather than showing them your product or service.

3. Asking the wrong questions:

If you ask closed-ended questions that don't encourage the prospect to share more information, you may not get a clear understanding of their needs or challenges.

4. Not listening actively:

If you're not actively listening to the prospect during the meeting, you may miss important details or opportunities to build rapport.

5. Focusing too much on selling:

If you're too focused on selling your product or service during the meeting, you may come across as pushy or not interested in the prospect's needs. This can damage the relationship and make it harder to close the deal later on.

If you want help building stronger relationships with your prospects, avoid these common pitfalls and set yourself up for success.

comments.commentText: well said! nothing worse than a discovery call that turns into a guessing game

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Effective discovery is crucial for building relationships. Preparation and active listening can make all the difference! ğŸŒŸ

Neil Sahota
Neil Sahota
postsData.content:
AI mind-reading: thrilling, but still a long way off. 

While breakthroughs in AI and neuroscience have made decoding brain signals possible, weâ€™re still far from reading minds like in sci-fi.

Current technologies can translate specific tasks like controlling a robotic arm, but they donâ€™t understand complex thoughts or emotions. And with the ethical concerns about privacy and data misuse, there's a lot to consider before mind-reading becomes a reality.

The idea of AI mind-reading is fascinating, but for now, weâ€™re just scratching the surface.

Could AI ever truly read minds?

comments.commentText: Thought privacy must be a fundamental right, even as AI technology continues to evolve.

postsData.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
postsData.content:
Donâ€™t overshare, you just might be targeted and terminated because of it. 

I hate to say this, but employers are targeting employees when they are most vulnerable. When they are going through life cycle events in their personal life. When personal tragedies happen.

When the employer no longer views the employee as valuable, or as effective, or reliable or focused as they were before.

Iâ€™ve have spoken to employees who were terminated
 before a wedding/honeymoon
 during/after a divorce
 before, during, and after parental leave
 after putting down a deposit on a house
 after breaking ground building a new home
 after disclosing an illness or medical condition
 while taking time off to care for a dying parent in hospice
 while recovering from complications associated with an organ transplant
 while recovering from the emotional trauma of a sexual assault
 while being a remote working having to relocate for medical care for a dying child or spouse
 and so many more that are just as bad if not worse.

I consulted with a kind and selfless manager who notified his employer that his wife had Parkinsonâ€™s disease.

He shared that he might be distracted over the coming months and may have to take some intermittent FMLA to support his wife.

Despite working for the employer for more than 7 years, he was terminated within 2 months of the notification.

This is not an outlier. This is what happens in the dark, much more often than we could ever imagine while the loyal employee is scarred and damaged for a lifetime by the actions of their employer.

Only share when you must. When it will benefit you to do so. When your job is at stake if you donâ€™t.

Otherwise share as little as possible with your leadership about the important things in your life. They just might use if against you. They are not your family or friends.

comments.commentText: Where is HR?
Dean Wiener where's Waldo?
Dean Wiener Already posting your job on forums. HR is ultimately there to protect the company.

I would caution that these unfortunate observations about bad behavior should not to be taken as a broad endictments of humanity, as the posting comes across, but as the specific failures of certain toxic businesses or industries. The world is admittedly riddled with horrible businesses and woefully inept leadership. However, it also is teeming with wonderful and supportive work environments.

Find the right job, where you can appropriately be who you are, and feel safe to share relevant personal dynamics, within a reliably supportive professional environment.

postsData.commentAdded: This is an important reminder about workplace vulnerability. Protecting your personal life can safeguard your career. Choose wisely when to share.

Radha Vyas

postsData.content:
They told me everything went downhill in midlife. 

They couldn't have been more wrong !! 

Here are 7 lies we're told about this life stage:

1/ "Youâ€™re past your prime."

â†³ Prime is about confidence, not age.
â†³ Iâ€™m healthier and more focused at 40+ than ever.
â†³ Midlife is when everything comes together.

2/ "Itâ€™s too late to start a business."

â†³ In 2020, I lost everything.
â†³ In 2021, I rebuilt Flash Pack from scratch.
â†³ Itâ€™s never too late to start, or restart.

3/ "You canâ€™t balance career and family."

â†³ Itâ€™s hard, but not impossible.
â†³ My husband and I split parenting 50/50.
â†³ Support systems are your saving grace.

4/ "Youâ€™re too old for adventure."

â†³ Midlife doesnâ€™t mean settling for boring.
â†³ Our 45+ travellers crave meaningful experiences.
â†³ Adventure doesn't have an expiration date.

5/ "Women lose value in the workplace."

â†³ Midlife women are leadership powerhouses.
â†³ Companies with 30% women leaders thrive.
â†³ The experience and resilience are unparalleled.

6/ "Success peaks in your 30s."

â†³ Success has no deadline.
â†³ The best moments in my career came after 40.
â†³ The average founder age? 45.

7/ "You canâ€™t change careers or industries."

â†³ Many midlife travellers reinvent themselves.
â†³ Some start businesses based on lifelong passions.
â†³ Reinvention in midlife isn't rare. It's encouraged.

Midlife isnâ€™t the end of the road.

Itâ€™s a profound turning point.

Itâ€™s the chapter where confidence, clarity, and experience come together. Where you stop doubting yourself and start going after what truly matters.

FAR from winding down...

Midlife is about levelling up!

Anyone else agree?

ï¸ Repost to amplify this message.

_

 I'm, CEO & Co-Founder of, connecting solo travelers on life-changing social adventures.

Follow for daily posts on the journey!

comments.commentText: Midlife is the perfect time to embrace reinvention and redefine your purpose. It's about embracing the freedom to evolve into who you're meant to be next!

postsData.name:
Anthony Natoli
Anthony Natoli
postsData.content:
I've booked 2 meetings in the past week using this 1 simple filter in LinkedIn Sales Navigator... "Changed Jobs".. Here are the steps and the not so obvious things to do:

Step 1: Upload YOUR book of business
Step 2: Go to lead filters
Step 3: Go to Current Company = Your Book of Business
Step 4: Click "Changed Jobs"
Step 5: Find titles relevant to your ICP
Step 6: Do not email them and just say "congrats on your role - want to meet?"
Step 7: Please create a compelling reason why you are reaching out beyond them starting a new role... Perhaps a "problem statement" and call out that once they get settled it would be great to meet because of XYZ -- you can also send them a coffee and say "as you ramp up, enjoy a few morning coffees on me as you watch those onboarding videos!"

BONUS: Filter by "past customer" or "past company = customer list"

This will give you previous users / customers of your product.

That is all.

Want more Natoli's Nuggets like this? I go deep every Sunday on topics like sales & making sure you feel good outside of work, too. Join 5k+ others here

comments.commentText: this is solid!! simple but effective

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Simple yet effective steps to leverage LinkedIn for building connections. Excited to try this approach! #NetworkingNuggets

postsData.name:
Chandler Cutler
Chandler Cutler
postsData.content:
Why Most Software Fails to Get Adopted (And How to Fix It)

Hereâ€™s the hard truth: Even the best software means nothing if no one knows how to use it.

Too many companies launch a tool, drop some documentation, and expect users to figure it out. But humans resist change. Learning something new feels overwhelmingâ€”until it doesnâ€™t.

, CEO of, breaks it down:

1ï¸âƒ£ Simplify the learning curve â€“ The easier it is to start, the faster adoption happens.

2ï¸âƒ£ Support beats self-service â€“ Even a simple platform needs guidance. Hands-on support ensures users donâ€™t get stuck.

3ï¸âƒ£ Meet customers where they are â€“ Some teams have 300+ users. Training needs to be scalable, structured, and ongoing.

Adoption isnâ€™t just about features. Itâ€™s about making sure people actually use them.

Thatâ€™s how you turn software into a habitâ€”and a habit into success.

postsData.content:
I built all my businesses with my life partner.

Not because of skills.
Not because of funding.
Not because of strategy.

Because great partnerships arenâ€™t chosen.
Theyâ€™re built.

Most founders look for:
â†’ Technical expertise
â†’ Industry experience
â†’ Network access
â†’ Capital contribution

But the partnerships that last decades
look for something deeper:

1. Wisdom over intelligence
Sees what others ignore.

2. Partnership over ego
Success is ours, not mine.

3. Resilience over reaction
No blame. Just solutions.

4. Skin in the game
Risks, not just opinions.

5. Joy in the journey
Even the worst days feel lighter.

Want a partner like that?
BE that partner first.

 Share credit freely
 Stand strong in crisis
 Choose trust over control
 Add fun to the grind

I built my biggest wins on trust.
Shared dreams. Zero politics.
In success and setbacks.

Looking for a co-founder?

Stop checking resumes.
Start checking for these traits.
Above all, build these in yourself.

Image credit: Illustration from Poor Charlie's Almanack 3rd edition.

postsData.name:
Sheena Hakimian
Sheena Hakimian
postsData.content:
10 Behaviors That Make You Look Like a Follower, Not a Leader

(And how to create impact with simple shifts.)

I used to fall into the trap of being a follower:
â†³ I didnâ€™t take initiative.
â†³ I waited to be told what to do.
â†³ I stayed silent, even when I disagreed.

But over time, my confidence grew. I learned that leadership isnâ€™t about titlesâ€”itâ€™s about actions.

Anyone can lead. Anyone can create impact.

Here are 10 behaviors that make you look like a follower, not a leader (and how to fix them):

1ï¸âƒ£ Always waiting for permission
â†³ Followers wait to be told what to do. Leaders take initiative.
â†³ Identify problems and propose solutions without being asked.

2ï¸âƒ£ Avoiding tough conversations
â†³ Dodging conflict makes you seem passive.
â†³ Prepare for difficult conversations by writing down the facts and key points.

3ï¸âƒ£ Never offering new ideas
â†³ Staying silent in meetings makes people think you are disengaged.
â†³ Prepare 1-2 ideas before every meeting, even if small.

4ï¸âƒ£ Over-apologizing
â†³ Constantly saying â€œsorryâ€ makes you seem insecure.
â†³ Reflect on whether an apology is really necessary before saying it.

5ï¸âƒ£ Over-explaining your decisions
â†³ Justifying everything makes you seem unsure.
â†³ State your decision clearly, then stop: â€œI believe this is the best approach becauseâ€¦â€

6ï¸âƒ£ Being too agreeable
â†³ Saying â€œyesâ€ to everything shows a lack of critical thinking.
â†³ Politely challenge ideas with phrases like, â€œHave we considered this angle instead?â€

7ï¸âƒ£ Relying too much on your manager
â†³ Always leaning on your boss signals you canâ€™t operate independently.
â†³ Before asking for help, outline 2-3 possible solutions to the problem.

8ï¸âƒ£ Avoiding visibility
â†³ Hiding behind your work makes you forgettable.
â†³ Volunteer for stretch projects that challenge and highlight your skills.

9ï¸âƒ£ Deflecting credit
â†³ Downplaying your contributions makes you look unsure about your value.
â†³ Acknowledge the team while owning your role: â€œIt was a great team effort, and I led X.â€

 Complaining without solutions
â†³ Venting about problems without action makes you seem powerless.
â†³ Pair every complaint with at least one solution.

If you want to be seen as a leader, start showing up as one.

Which one of these behaviors surprised you the most? Do you have any to add? Let me know in the comments!

P.S. If you want in-depth personal and career growth advice, sign up for my coaching style newsletter! You can find the link under my name

__
ï¸ Repost to inspire people in your network!
 Followfor daily tips like this!

comments.commentText: I used to over-apologize for everything, thinking it made me more approachableâ€”but it really just undermined my confidence. The shift came when I realized it isnâ€™t about pleasing everyone, but owning your decisions.

I agee, Martina! It so much better to be known as a clear thinker who can commit to a path. (Plus, who wants to go through life feeling sorry?)

Love this breakdown of follower vs. leader behaviors, Sheena. You've broken down the behaviors that make someone look like a follower and provided actionable shifts to create IMPACT. Great advice for anyone wanting to level up.
David Brier thank you! Impact comes when you take those small steps

postsData.content:
Procrastination is the #1 killer of dreams.

Not failure.
Not lack of talent.
Not bad luck.

Just waiting too long to do what you know you need to do.

I had a fraternity brother who swore procrastination was his superpower.

He said he did his best work when the pressure was on.

I thought it was dumb then.

I know itâ€™s dumb now.

Because the truth?

Procrastination isnâ€™t a superpower, itâ€™s self sabotage.

It keeps you stuck in the life you have instead of building the life you want.

And most people never escape that cycle.

In this weekâ€™s Meaningful Momentum, I break down:

 Why we procrastinate (hint: itâ€™s not laziness)
 How to rewire your brain to stop pushing things off
 The single biggest mindset shift to take action immediately

This might be the most important post Iâ€™ve ever written.

Because the only difference between where you are and where youâ€™re meant to be is what you do TODAY!

Donâ€™t wait on this one.

Click the link, your future self is counting on it.

comments.commentText:
Great message. For a very long time I had no idea what I wanted to do, but by just attacking, I a) became stronger and b) figured out my path.

I believe this is true for anyone. We've just got to do as much raw action as possible to get us out of that unknown phase
Joseph Wheatley 1000%!! Iâ€™ve done a ton in my career and it took raw (sometimes undisciplined) action to get me to where I am today! The only way you refine is to start and make mistakes

Ned Arick I love this. Curious to hear more what you mean by undisciplined action? I think I resonate with this a little. If we try and be too disciplined we can end up gritting our teeth when we should have followed our nose.

We can only be the best at something that resonates deep I think

The 2-Minute Rule (the one you mentioned in the newsletter) is something I use every day. I break every task into tiny pieces, and starting + continuing no longer feels overwhelming. Itâ€™s almost like using LEGO blocks to build something. Itâ€™s fun and easy.

As for procrastination, Iâ€™m only now understanding what works for me, finally leaving space only for tasks that generate energy. Thatâ€™s when my brain actually collaborates, haha.

Victoria Rudi Love that! the 2 minute rule was such a game changer for me. And it really is important to understand what works for you when it comes to overcoming procrastination. For me it was the 2 minute rule and the accountability.

postsData.name:
Jake Dunlap
Jake Dunlap
postsData.content:
Meetings arenâ€™t work

Work is when you turn your brain on, think critically and solve problems

Here is what I do to cut down on meetings and get more of what matters done

1. Asynchronous video updates - donâ€™t schedule a meeting to get feedback on a deck, send a video talking through it. People can watch at 1.25 speed and get better feedback faster

2. Get ruthless about adding priorities. When we talk in leadership about something being a new priority the question is â€œshould this wait until next quarter with everything going?â€ The answer usually is yes

More priorities = more meetings

Make sure your team has at least one slightly annoying, in a good way, person  who isnâ€™t an internal optimist. You need people to ground the conversation is positive but constructive way. This person helps to poke holes in why it may not be priority so you donâ€™t have to have more meetings on it.

3. Delegate - I loves book Buy Back Your Time. He has a saying â€œ80% done by someone else is 100% *bleeping* awesomeâ€.

You probably can delegate a meeting here or there that will empower someone else

Look at your week? Find at least 8-10 hours to do some real work and see how rewarding work can actually be
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Love the idea of async video updates and prioritizing effectively. Hereâ€™s to more focused work and less meeting fatigue! ğŸš€

postsData.name:
Rohit Sakunia
Rohit Sakunia
postsData.content:
Leadership isnâ€™t about control.

Itâ€™s about empowerment.

The best bosses donâ€™t micromanage.
Or demand respect.

They create an environment .
Where people feel valued, motivated, and supported.

A bad boss does the opposite.
 Drains energy,
 Stalls growth,
 Makes work feel like a struggle.

These red flags
 Undermine your confidence instead of building it.
 Block your growth instead of encouraging it.
 Create stress instead of clarity.

 Here are 11 signs itâ€™s time to change your boss:
(and how to manage each one)


1ï¸âƒ£ Your manager takes credit for your work.
â†’ Document contributions and share updates publicly.
â†’ Loop in leadership when discussing key projects.

2ï¸âƒ£ Your manager doesnâ€™t give you feedback.
â†’ Ask directly for performance insights.
â†’ Request specific areas for improvement.

3ï¸âƒ£ Your manager micromanages.
â†’ Proactively update them before they ask.
â†’ Clarify expectations and request autonomy.

4ï¸âƒ£ Your manager excludes you from opportunities.
â†’ Express interest in key projects.
â†’ Seek mentorship outside your team.

5ï¸âƒ£ Your manager overloads you with menial tasks.
â†’ Prioritize key work and push back.
â†’ Request tasks that match your skills.

6ï¸âƒ£ Your manager offers no support.
â†’ Find guidance from peers or mentors.
â†’ Take initiative in problem-solving.

7ï¸âƒ£ Your manager always highlights mistakes.
â†’ Ask for constructive solutions, not blame.
â†’ Keep a record of positive contributions.

8ï¸âƒ£ Your manager doesnâ€™t advocate for you.
â†’ Build relationships with senior leaders.
â†’ Speak up about your achievements.

9ï¸âƒ£ Your manager sets moving goals.
â†’ Get clear expectations in writing.
â†’ Track progress and follow up consistently.

 Your manager plays favorites.
â†’ Focus on delivering strong results.
â†’ Build connections across different teams.

1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Your manager doesnâ€™t help you grow.
â†’ Seek learning opportunities independently.
â†’ Invest in skills outside of work.

Remeber,
The best leaders:
 Uplift their teams, not undermine them.
 Lead with fairness, clarity, and support.
 Create opportunities instead of limiting potential.


Have you ever dealt with a difficult boss?
How did you handle it?
Share your experience in the comments!

comments.commentText:
It would be an insane choice to skip this one. 

 Sign up now: https://hubs.la/Q032JjSB0
Interested in hearing your thoughts on branded vs non-branded calls.
Michael Bunch I donâ€™t know what that means. Tell me more?

Branded calling is when you display your company name on the recipient's phone during outbound dials, so they know it's you calling. Sherry Patton helps companies do this.

Personally, I've done a lot of A/B testing with branded vs non-branded, and though my answer rates weren't too different, my engagement and win rates were better with branded calls. My hypothesis is those who want to buy from you are the ones likely to answer your branded call.

postsData.commentAdded: Excited to hear your insights on cold calling! Your experience is invaluableâ€”canâ€™t wait to learn more about your call opener strategies!

comments.commentText:
Now that you mention it, I can see mine is pretty terrible. Thank you for helping! 
Currently it reads:
Jungian Life Coach & Innovator | Shaping tools and insights to guide clients to breakthroughs in relationships, leadership, and life.

What I actually do is help people develop dormant parts of their personality and turn their crap into gold. Can you help me communicate that? Thank you so much!
